The subsequent softmax layer hence outputs: | | | | | | --- | --- | --- | --- | | | P‚Äã(y=k\|ùíõ)={q‚Äã(ùíõ=k\|ùíô)‚àëk=1Kq‚Äã(ùíõ=k\|ùíô), if ‚Äãk=arg‚Äãminj‚Äã‚Äñze‚Äã(ùíô)‚àíej‚Äñ220, otherwiseùëÉùë¶conditionalùëòùíõcasesùëûùíõconditionalùëòùíôsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1ùêæùëûùíõconditionalùëòùíô if ùëòsubscriptargminùëósuperscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptùëßùëíùíôsubscriptùëíùëó220 otherwise\\displaystyle P(y=k\|\\boldsymbol{z})=\\begin{cases}\\frac{q(\\boldsymbol{z}=k\|\\boldsymbol{x})}{\\sum\_{k=1}^{K}q(\\boldsymbol{z}=k\|\\boldsymbol{x})},&\\text{ if }k=\\operatorname\*{arg\\,min}\_{j}\\left\|\\left\|z\_{e}(\\boldsymbol{x})-e\_{j}\\right\|\\right\|\_{2}^{2}\\\

4 Experiments.content:
The expression profile data used in this study were collected from the world‚Äôs largest cancer gene information database Genomic Data Commons (GDC) portal.
All of the used expression data were generated from cancer samples prior to treatment.

We utilized the expression profiles of three representative types of cancer for experiments:

- ‚Ä¢


Breast invasive carcinoma (BRCA): BRCA is the most prevalent cancer in the world. Its expression profiles were collected from the Illumina Hi-Seq platform and the Illumina GA platform.

- ‚Ä¢


Brain lower grade glioma (LGG): the expression profiles were collected from the Illumina Hi-Seq platform.

- ‚Ä¢


Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM): the expression profiles were collected from the Agilent array platform. Results on this dataset are deferred to the appendix.


These datasets consist of continuous-valued expression profiles (feature length: 11327) of 639, 417 and 452 subjects, respectively.
Additional experimental results and hyperparameters can be seen in Appendix Section A available at [https://arxiv.org/abs/2206.10801].

The experimental section is organized as follows:
we first compare the clustering results with the ground truth labels ùí¥g‚Äãtsubscriptùí¥ùëîùë°\\mathcal{Y}\_{gt} in Section [4.1]Ground Truth Comparison ‚Ä£ 4 Experiments ‚Ä£ Automated Cancer Subtyping via Vector Quantization Mutual Information Maximization") to validate the proposed method.
We show in Section [4.2]Controversial Label Comparison ‚Ä£ 4 Experiments ‚Ä£ Automated Cancer Subtyping via Vector Quantization Mutual Information Maximization") that VQ-RIM consistenly re-assigns subjects to different subtypes and produces one more potential subtype with enlarged separation in between-group life expectancies, which in turn suggests VQ-RIM is capable of better capturing the underlying characteristics of subtypes.
Extensive ablation studies on both the categorical generator (VQ-VAE) and the information maximizing discriminator (RIM) are performed to validate the proposed architecture in Section [4.3]Ablation Study ‚Ä£ 4 Experiments ‚Ä£ Automated Cancer Subtyping via Vector Quantization Mutual Information Maximization").
We believe the VQ-RIM subtyping result is far-reaching and can provide important new insights to the unsettled debate on cancer subtyping.

### 4.1 Ground Truth Comparison

![Refer to caption]Figure 2: Comparison between ùí¥g‚Äãtsubscriptùí¥ùëîùë°\\mathcal{Y}\_{gt} and the VQ-RIM label yùë¶y on the Basal-like subtype of BRCA.

For validating the correctness of VQ-RIM, we show an example in Figure [2]Figure 2 ‚Ä£ 4.1 Ground Truth Comparison ‚Ä£ 4 Experiments ‚Ä£ Automated Cancer Subtyping via Vector Quantization Mutual Information Maximization"), i.e., the Basal-like cancer subtype of BRCA that has been well-studied and extensively validated by human experts and can be confidently subtyped, which can be exploited as the ground-truth labels ùí¥g‚Äãtsubscriptùí¥ùëîùë°\\mathcal{Y}\_{gt}.

However, other subtypes lack such well-verified labels and are regarded as the controversial labels ùí¥csubscriptùí¥ùëê\\mathcal{Y}\_{c}.
The left subfigure of Figure [2]Figure 2 ‚Ä£ 4.1 Ground Truth Comparison ‚Ä£ 4 Experiments ‚Ä£ Automated Cancer Subtyping via Vector Quantization Mutual Information Maximization") shows the two principal axes of Basal-like expression profiles after PCA.
The blue triangles in the right subfigure indicates the difference between ùí¥g‚Äãtsubscriptùí¥ùëîùë°\\mathcal{Y}\_{gt} and the VQ-RIM result.
It can be seen that VQ-RIM agrees well with the ground truth.

### 4.2 Controversial Label Comparison

#### 4.2.1 Subtype Comparison.

We compare existing controversial labels ùí¥csubscriptùí¥ùëê\\mathcal{Y}\_{c} with the clustering results of VQ-RIM in Figure [3]Figure 3 ‚Ä£ 4.2.1 Subtype Comparison. ‚Ä£ 4.2 Controversial Label Comparison ‚Ä£ 4 Experiments ‚Ä£ Automated Cancer Subtyping via Vector Quantization Mutual Information Maximization").
VQ-RIM output sensible decision boundaries that separated the data well and consistently produced one more subtype than ùí¥csubscriptùí¥ùëê\\mathcal{Y}\_{c}.
As confirmed in Section [4.1]Ground Truth Comparison ‚Ä£ 4 Experiments ‚Ä£ Automated Cancer Subtyping via Vector Quantization Mutual Information Maximization"), the Basal-like subtype concorded well with the VQ-RIM Cluster A.
On the other hand, other subtypes exhibited significant differences:
controversial labels seem to compactly fit into a fan-like shape in the two-dimensional visualization.
This is owing to the human experts‚Äô heuristics in subtyping: intuitively, the similarity of tumors in the clinical variables such as morphological appearance often renders them being classified into an identical subtype.
However, cancer subtypes are the result of complicated causes on the molecular level.
Two main observations can be made from the BRCA VQ-RIM label:
(1) Luminal A was divided into three distinct clusters C,D,E.
Cluster E now occupies the left and right wings of the fan which are separated by Cluster B and C;
(2) A new subtype Cluster F emerged from Luminal B, which was indistinguishable from Cluster E if na√Øvely viewed from the visualization.
This counter-intuitive clustering result confirmed the complexity of cancer subtypes in expression profiles seldom admits simple representations as was done in the controversial labels.
A similar conclusion holds as well for other datasets such as LGG:
IDH mut-codel was divided into two distinct subtypes (Cluster A, B), among which the new subtype Cluster A found by VQ-RIM occupied the right wing of IDH mut-codel.
In later subsections, the one more cluster and re-assignment of VQ-RIM are justified by analyzing the subtype population and from a medical point of view.
Due to page limit, we provide analysis focusing on BRCA only.

![Refer to caption]Figure 3: PCA visualization of the first two principal axes for BRCA and LGG.
![Refer to caption]Figure 4:
(a) t-SNE visualization of the sample distribution on BRCA.
(b) t-SNE of the samples with controversial labels.
(c) label flows from the controversial labels (left) to VQ-RIM 5 subtypes (mid) and 6 subtypes (right).

#### 4.2.2 Label Flows.

The controversial labels might run the risk of _over-simplifying assignment_ which refers to that in the regions overlapped with several distinct subtypes, controversial labels put all subjects into one of them without further identifying their sources.
Such assignment can be illustrated by Figure [4]Figure 4 ‚Ä£ 4.2.1 Subtype Comparison. ‚Ä£ 4.2 Controversial Label Comparison ‚Ä£ 4 Experiments ‚Ä£ Automated Cancer Subtyping via Vector Quantization Mutual Information Maximization").
Here, Figure ( [4]Figure 4 ‚Ä£ 4.2.1 Subtype Comparison. ‚Ä£ 4.2 Controversial Label Comparison ‚Ä£ 4 Experiments ‚Ä£ Automated Cancer Subtyping via Vector Quantization Mutual Information Maximization") a) plots the sample distribution with darker colors indicating denser population of samples.
It is visible that the samples can be assigned to five clusters.
However, by injecting subtyping label information it is clear from Figure ( [4]Figure 4 ‚Ä£ 4.2.1 Subtype Comparison. ‚Ä£ 4.2 Controversial Label Comparison ‚Ä£ 4 Experiments ‚Ä£ Automated Cancer Subtyping via Vector Quantization Mutual Information Maximization") b) that in the lower left corner there existed strong overlaps of three different subtypes.
Controversial labels assigned them to a single subtype Luminal A.
VQ-RIM, on the other hand, was capable of separating those three subtypes.
This separation can be seen from Figure ( [4]Figure 4 ‚Ä£ 4.2.1 Subtype Comparison. ‚Ä£ 4.2 Controversial Label Comparison ‚Ä£ 4 Experiments ‚Ä£ Automated Cancer Subtyping via Vector Quantization Mutual Information Maximization") c) which compares the two labeling when setting the number of VQ-RIM subtypes to 5 in accordance with controversial labels, or to 6 by setting KùêæK to a sufficiently large value and automatically determines the suitable number of subtypes.
In either case, VQ-RIM consistently separated the Luminal A into three distinct subtypes: (B,C,E) in 5 subtypes case and (C\*, D\*, E\*) in the 6 subtypes case.
In the next subsection, we verify the effectiveness of such finer-grained subtyping by performing survival analysis.

#### 4.2.3 Medical evaluation.

![Refer to caption]Figure 5: Kaplan-Meier survival analysis within each identified subtype group (right) compared with original subtyping system (left) as a baseline.
The line in different colors represent patients from different subtypes.
P-value was calculated by Kaplan‚ÄìMeier analysis with the log-rank test.

To demonstrate the clinical relevance of the identified subtypes, we perform subtype-specific survival analysis by the Kaplan-Meier (KM) estimate.

KM estimate is one of the most frequently used statistical methods for survival analysis, which we use to complementarily validate the VQ-RIM labels from a clinical point of view \[ [16])\].
KM compares survival probabilities in a given length of time between different sample groups.
The KM estimator is given by:
S^=‚àèi:t<itni‚àídini\\widehat{S}=\\prod\_{i:t{{}\_{i}}<t}\\frac{n\_{i}-d\_{i}}{n\_{i}},
where nisubscriptùëõùëñn\_{i} is the number of samples under observation at time iùëñi and disubscriptùëëùëñd\_{i} is the number of individuals dying at time iùëñi.
The survival analysis graph is plotted between estimated survival probabilities (on Y-axis) and the time passed after samples entry into the study (on X-axis),
where the survival curve is drawn as a step function and falls only when a subject dies.

We can compare curves for different subtypes by examining gaps between the curves in horizontal or vertical direction.
A vertical gap means that at a specific time point,
samples belonging to one subtype had a greater fraction of surviving,
while a horizontal one means that it takes longer for these samples to experience a certain fraction of deaths.
The survival curves can also be compared statistically by testing the null hypothesis, i.e. there is no difference regarding survival situation among different groups,
which can be tested by classical methods like the log-rank test and the Cox proportional hazard test.

Figure [5]Figure 5 ‚Ä£ 4.2.3 Medical evaluation. ‚Ä£ 4.2 Controversial Label Comparison ‚Ä£ 4 Experiments ‚Ä£ Automated Cancer Subtyping via Vector Quantization Mutual Information Maximization") shows the KM survival analysis graph for BRCA samples, based on the PAM50 subtyping system and VQ-RIM subtypes.
Compared with the PAM50, the survival curves of VQ-RIM subtypes are more significantly separated.
Log-rank test also shows that there is significant difference in between-group survival with a smaller pùëùp-value of 0.0023 compared against the PAM50 (ùí¥csubscriptùí¥ùëê\\mathcal{Y}\_{c}).

Smaller pùëùp-values indicate better subtyping results.

We indicate the subtype-specific median survival time with dashed lines.
It is visible that VQ-RIM performed better in identifying subtypes with large median survival time differences.

### 4.3 Ablation Study

![Refer to caption]Figure 6: PCA visualization of the first two principal axes for BRCA using different clustering methods.
The number of cluster number is determined by ùí¥csubscriptùí¥ùëê\\mathcal{Y}\_{c} (PAM50).![Refer to caption]Figure 7: The number of clustering is determined by combining the results from the elbow method, not used for RIM.

In this section, we conduct comprehensive ablation experiments to further strengthen the effectiveness of VQ-RIM.
Specifically, we validate the VQ part and RIM part respectively by comparing VQ-RIM against the following combinations:

- ‚Ä¢


we replace the VQ part with AE and VAEs with continuous latent which have been exploited for subtyping in \[ [31]), [33])\]. The expression profiles are compressed into continuous latent feature spaces for subsequent RIM clustering.

- ‚Ä¢


we replace the RIM part with existing classic clustering algorithms such as K-Means, spectral clustering, and Gaussian mixture models \[ [3])\]. Categorical latent variables from VQ-VAE are fed into them for subtyping.


Results of the ablation studies can be seen by inspecting Figure [6]Figure 6 ‚Ä£ 4.3 Ablation Study ‚Ä£ 4 Experiments ‚Ä£ Automated Cancer Subtyping via Vector Quantization Mutual Information Maximization") row-wise and column-wise, respectively.
All methods applied ùí¥csubscriptùí¥ùëê\\mathcal{Y}\_{c} (PAM50) for labeling.
By inspecting the results row-wise, a first observation is that for all clustering methods AE and VAE tended to disperse data points.
On the other hand, it can be seen from VQ-VAE clustering that subjects from distinct subtypes compactly located in lower-dimensional spaces.
Column-wise inspection indicates that compared to other clustering methods, RIM tended to more cohesively aggregate the in-group points:
by contrast, it is visible from the VAE row that only Basal-like subjects were cohesively grouped.
Among all compared methods, VQ-RIM stood out as the subjects were located in lower dimensional spaces from which clear decision boundaries emerged.
The clear separation of VQ-RIM can be attributed to the underlying nearest neighbor search: such search essentially performed a preliminary grouping on the data, which greatly facilitated later separation.
This observation is consistent with the recent finding of pseudo-labeling that explicitly performs K-means in creating preliminary clusters \[ [20])\].
Besides the aforementioned qualitative evaluation, we also quantitatively measure in Table [1]Table 1 ‚Ä£ 4.3 Ablation Study ‚Ä£ 4 Experiments ‚Ä£ Automated Cancer Subtyping via Vector Quantization Mutual Information Maximization") the scores of all the clustering results in Figure [6]Figure 6 ‚Ä£ 4.3 Ablation Study ‚Ä£ 4 Experiments ‚Ä£ Automated Cancer Subtyping via Vector Quantization Mutual Information Maximization") by using the three well-accepted metrics: Normalized Mutual Information (NMI), Sihouette coefficient scores (Silhouette) and pùëùp-value of survival analysis \[ [17])\].

However, in Section [4.2]Controversial Label Comparison ‚Ä£ 4 Experiments ‚Ä£ Automated Cancer Subtyping via Vector Quantization Mutual Information Maximization"), the labeling ùí¥csubscriptùí¥ùëê\\mathcal{Y}\_{c} might not be the best medically even if the clustering result accords well with human intuition.
In Figure [7]Figure 7 ‚Ä£ 4.3 Ablation Study ‚Ä£ 4 Experiments ‚Ä£ Automated Cancer Subtyping via Vector Quantization Mutual Information Maximization") we focus on VQ-VAE, and set the number of clusters for RIM to a sufficiently large value and let RIM automatically determines a suitable number of subtypes.
We term this strategy automatic VQ-VAE in the last row of Table
[1]Table 1 ‚Ä£ 4.3 Ablation Study ‚Ä£ 4 Experiments ‚Ä£ Automated Cancer Subtyping via Vector Quantization Mutual Information Maximization").

For other clustering algorithms, the number of clusters is determined from the Silhouette coefficient scores and the elbow method \[ [17])\].
It is visible that clustering algorithms other than RIM tended to reduce the number of subtypes for higher scores.
By contrast, VQ-RIM produced one more subtype.
This automatic VQ-RIM clustering was superior from a medical perspective since it achieved greatest subtyping result as demonstrated by the smallest pùëùp-value of 0.0023.
Furthermore, algorithmically it is better than plain VQ-RIM as it achieved the highest scores of 0.63 and 0.54 of NMI and Silhouette among all ablation choices.

Table 1:
Metrics used for measuring the clustering results of Figure [6]Figure 6 ‚Ä£ 4.3 Ablation Study ‚Ä£ 4 Experiments ‚Ä£ Automated Cancer Subtyping via Vector Quantization Mutual Information Maximization") and [7]Figure 7 ‚Ä£ 4.3 Ablation Study ‚Ä£ 4 Experiments ‚Ä£ Automated Cancer Subtyping via Vector Quantization Mutual Information Maximization").
The top three rows show the number of clustering determined by ùí¥csubscriptùí¥ùëê\\mathcal{Y}\_{c} (PAM50), while the last row shows the number of clustering is automatically determined.

| Generator | Discriminator | NMI‚Üë‚Üë\\uparrow | Silhouette‚Üë‚Üë\\uparrow | pùëùp-value‚Üì‚Üì\\downarrow |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| AE + | K-Means | 0.34 | 0.13 | 0.0861 |

5 Discussion and Conclusion.content:
In this paper we were concerned with the cancer subtyping problem that aimed to disclose the difference between subtypes within a specific cancer.
Existing literature is having an unsettled debate over the subtyping problem, with various definition and suitable number of subtypes put forward from distinct viewpoints.
Aiming to aid the medical experts by providing dependable reference for subtyping, we took a data-scientific standpoint and exploited genetic expression profiles of cancers without using the controversial labels current literature has imposed.
Such genetic expression profiles featured scarcity, high dimensionality, and complicated dependence which posed challenges for both physicians and data scientists.
To tackle these problems, we leveraged information-theoretic principles as well as recent categorical latent generative modeling techniques that helped in minimizing clustering confusion and maximizing interpretability.
The resultant novel model: Vector Quantization Regularized Information Maximization (VQ-RIM) can better reveal the intrinsic difference between cancer genetic expression profiles and based on which automatically decide a suitable number of subtypes.
The experiment on ground-truth BRCA cancer verified the correctness of VQ-RIM, while more extensive experiments on multiple authoritative datasets consisting of various cancers showed the difference between VQ-RIM results and the controversial labels.
By comprehensive analysis from both data scientific and medical views, we illustrated that the different subtyping result yielded by VQ-RIM consistently outperformed existing ones in terms of survival analysis, and contributed important new insights into the unsettled debate.

The future work consists of two interesting directions:
(1) to further validate the effectiveness of VQ-RIM, comprehensive experiments on all available cancer datasets and comparison with their existing labeling might be necessary.
(2) the VQ-RIM architecture might not only work well with cancer data but also be generally applicable on radically different data such as images, voices that inherently exploit discrete nature of the data.

6 Acknowledgement.content: This work was supported by JST Mirai Program (JPMJMI20B8) and JST PRESTO (JPMJPR21C7), Japan.

bib.bib9.abstract:
Cancer subtyping is crucial for understanding the nature of tumors and
providing suitable therapy. However, existing labelling methods are medically
controversial, and have driven the process of subtyping away from teaching
signals. Moreover, cancer genetic expression profiles are high-dimensional,
scarce, and have complicated dependence, thereby posing a serious challenge to
existing subtyping models for outputting sensible clustering. In this study, we
propose a novel clustering method for exploiting genetic expression profiles
and distinguishing subtypes in an unsupervised manner. The proposed method
adaptively learns categorical correspondence from latent representations of
expression profiles to the subtypes output by the model. By maximizing the
problem -- agnostic mutual information between input expression profiles and
output subtypes, our method can automatically decide a suitable number of
subtypes. Through experiments, we demonstrate that our proposed method can
refine existing controversial labels, and, by further medical analysis, this
refinement is proven to have a high correlation with cancer survival rates.

bib.bib22.title: Deltacon: A principled massive-graph similarity function.
bib.bib22.venue: Proceedings of the 2013 SIAM international conference on data mining

1 Introduction.content:
Graphs arise naturally in numerous situations; social, traffic, collaboration and computer networks, images, protein-protein interaction networks, brain connectivity graphs and web graphs are only a few examples.
A problem that comes up often in all those settings is the following: how much do two graphs or networks differ in terms of connectivity?

Graph similarity (or comparison) is a core task for sense-making:
abnormal changes in the network traffic may indicate a computer attack; differences of big extent in a who-calls-whom graph may reveal a national celebration, or a telecommunication problem. Besides, network similarity can give insights into behavioral patterns: is the Facebook message graph similar to the Facebook wall-to-wall graph? Tracking changes in networks over time, spotting anomalies and detecting events is a research direction that has attracted much interest (e.g., \[ [1])\], \[ [2])\], \[ [3])\]).

![Refer to caption](a) Connectome: neural network of brain.

![Refer to caption](b) Dendogram representing the hierarchical clustering of the DeltaCon similarities between the 114 connectomes.

Figure 1: (a) Brain network (connectome). Different colors correspond to each of the 70 cortical regions, whose centers are depicted by vertices. Connections between the regions are shown by edges.
DeltaCon is used for clustering and classification.
(b) The connectomes are nicely classified in two big clusters by hierarchical clustering. The classification is based on the pairwise DeltaCon similarities between the 114 connectomes that we study. Elements in red correspond to high artistic score - thus, DeltaCon shows that artistic brains seem to have different wiring than the rest.

Long in the purview of researchers, graph similarity is a well-studied problem and several approaches have been proposed to solve variations of the problem. However, graph comparison still remains an open problem, while, with the passage of time, the list of requirements increases: the exponential growth of graphs, both in number and size, calls for methods that are not only accurate, but also scalable to graphs with billions of nodes.

In this paper, we address two main questions: How to compare two networks efficiently? How to evaluate their similarity score? Our main contributions are the following:
{enumerate\*}

_Axioms/Properties_: we formalize the axioms and properties that a similarity measure must conform to.

_Algorithm_: we propose DeltaCon for measuring connectivity differences between two graphs, and show that it is: (a) _principled_, conforming to all the axioms presented in Section [2]Proposed Method: Intuition ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function"), (b) _intuitive_, giving similarity scores that agree with common sense and can be easily explained, and (c) _scalable_, able to handle large-scale graphs.

_Experiments_: we report experiments on synthetic and real datasets, and compare DeltaCon to six state-of-the-art methods that apply to our setting.

_Applications_: We use DeltaCon for real-world applications, such as temporal anomaly detection and clustering/classification. In Fig. [1]Figure 1 ‚Ä£ 1 Introduction ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function"), DeltaCon is used for clustering brain graphs corresponding to 114 individuals; the two big clusters which differ in terms of connectivity correspond to people with high and low creativity. More details are given in Sec. [5]DeltaCon at Work ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function").

The paper is organized as follows: Section [2]Proposed Method: Intuition ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function") presents the intuition behind our method, and the axioms and desired properties of a similarity measure; Sec. [3]Proposed Method: Details ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function") has the proposed algorithms; experiments on synthetic and big real networks are in Sec. [4]Experiments ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function"); Sec. How can we find the similarity in connectivity between two graphs, or more formally how can we solve the following problem?

###### Problem 1

DeltaConnectivity
{description\*}

(a) two graphs, G1‚Äã(ùí±,‚Ñ∞1)subscriptùê∫1ùí±subscript‚Ñ∞1G\_{1}(\\mathcal{V},\\mathcal{E}\_{1}) and G2‚Äã(ùí±,‚Ñ∞2)subscriptùê∫2ùí±subscript‚Ñ∞2G\_{2}(\\mathcal{V},\\mathcal{E}\_{2}) with the same node set111If the graphs have different, but overlapping, node sets ùí±1subscriptùí±1\\mathcal{V}\_{1} and ùí±2subscriptùí±2\\mathcal{V}\_{2}, we assume that ùí±=ùí±1‚à™ùí±2ùí±subscriptùí±1subscriptùí±2\\mathcal{V}=\\mathcal{V}\_{1}\\cup\\mathcal{V}\_{2}, and the extra nodes are treated as singletons., ùí±ùí±\\mathcal{V}, and different edge sets ‚Ñ∞1subscript‚Ñ∞1\\mathcal{E}\_{1} and ‚Ñ∞2subscript‚Ñ∞2\\mathcal{E}\_{2}, and (b) the node correspondence.

a similarity score, s‚Äãi‚Äãm‚Äã(G1,G2)‚àà\[0,1\]ùë†ùëñùëösubscriptùê∫1subscriptùê∫201sim(G\_{1},G\_{2})\\in\[0,1\], between the input graphs. Similarity score of value 0 means totally different graphs, while 1 means identical graphs.

The obvious way to solve this problem is by measuring the overlap of their edges.
Why does this often not work in practice? Consider the following example: according to the overlap method, the pairs of barbell graphs shown in Fig. [2]Figure 2 ‚Ä£ 4.1 Intuitiveness of DeltaCon. ‚Ä£ 4 Experiments ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function") of p. [2]Figure 2 ‚Ä£ 4.1 Intuitiveness of DeltaCon. ‚Ä£ 4 Experiments ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function"), (B‚Äã10,m‚ÄãB‚Äã10)ùêµ10ùëöùêµ10(B10,mB10) and (B‚Äã10,m‚Äãm‚ÄãB‚Äã10)ùêµ10ùëöùëöùêµ10(B10,mmB10), have the same similarity score. But, clearly, from the aspect of information flow, a missing edge from a clique (m‚ÄãB‚Äã10)ùëöùêµ10(mB10) does not play as important role in the graph connectivity as the missing ‚Äúbridge‚Äù in m‚Äãm‚ÄãB‚Äã10ùëöùëöùêµ10mmB10. So, could we instead measure the differences in the 1-step away neighborhoods, 2-step away neighborhoods etc.? If yes, with what weight? It turns out (Intuition [1]Intuition 1 ‚Ä£ 2.3 Why use Belief Propagation? ‚Ä£ 2 Proposed Method: Intuition ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function")) that our method does exactly this in a principled way.

### 2.1 Fundamental Concept

The first conceptual step of our proposed method is
to compute the pairwise node affinities in the first graph,
and compare them with the ones in the second graph.
For notational compactness,
we store them in a n√ónùëõùëõn\\times n
similarity matrix222In reality, we don‚Äôt measure all the affinities (see Section [3.2]Scalability Analysis ‚Ä£ 3 Proposed Method: Details ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function") for an efficient approximation).ùêíùêí\\mathbf{S}.
The si‚Äãjsubscriptùë†ùëñùëós\_{ij} entry of the matrix indicates the influence node iùëñi has on node jùëój. For example, in a who-knows-whom network,
if node iùëñi is, say, republican and if we assume homophily (i.e., neighbors are similar),
how likely is it that node jùëój is also republican?
Intuitively, node iùëñi has more influence/affinity to node jùëój
if there are many, short, heavily weighted paths from node iùëñi to jùëój.

The second conceptual step is to measure the differences in the corresponding node affinity scores of the two graphs and report the result as their similarity score.

### 2.2 How to measure node affinity?

Pagerank, personalized Random Walks with Restarts (RWR), lazy RWR, and the ‚Äúelectrical network analogy‚Äù technique are only a few of the methods that compute node affinities. We could have used Personalized RWR:
\[ùêà‚àí(1‚àíc)‚ÄãùêÄùêÉ‚àí1\]‚Äãs‚Üíi=c‚Äãe‚Üíi,delimited-\[\]ùêà1ùëêsuperscriptùêÄùêÉ1subscript‚Üíùë†ùëñùëêsubscript‚Üíùëíùëñ\[\\mathbf{I}-(1-c)\\mathbf{A}\\mathbf{D}^{-1}\]{\\vec{s}}\_{i}=c\\;\\vec{e}\_{i},where cùëêc is the probability of restarting the random walk from the initial node, e‚Üíisubscript‚Üíùëíùëñ\\vec{e}\_{i} the starting (seed) indicator vector (all zeros except 1 at position iùëñi), and s‚Üíisubscript‚Üíùë†ùëñ{\\vec{s}}\_{i} the unknown Personalized Pagerank column vector. Specifically, si‚Äãjsubscriptùë†ùëñùëós\_{ij} is the affinity of node jùëój w.r.t. node iùëñi. Fast Belief Propagation (FaBP), which is identical to Personalized RWR under specific conditions (see Theorem [2]Theorem 2 ‚Ä£ A.2 Connection between FaBP and Personalized RWR ‚Ä£ A Appendix ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function") in Appendix [A.2]A.2 Connection between FaBP and Personalized RWR ‚Ä£ A Appendix ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function") of \[ [6])\]).
We use a simplified form of it
(see Appendix [A.1]A.1 From Fast Belief Propagation (FaBP) to DeltaCon ‚Ä£ A Appendix ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function") in \[ [6])\])

### 2.3 Why use Belief Propagation?

The reasons we choose BP and its fast approximation
with Eq. ( [2.2]In 2.2 How to measure node affinity? ‚Ä£ 2 Proposed Method: Intuition ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function")) are: (a) it is based on sound theoretical background (maximum likelihood estimation on marginals),
(b) it is fast (linear on the number of edges), and (c) it
agrees with intuition, taking into account
not only direct neighbors, but also 2-, 3- and kùëòk-step-away
neighbors, with decreasing weight.
We elaborate on the last reason, next:

###### Intuition 1

\[Attenuating Neighboring Influence\]

By temporarily ignoring the term œµ2‚ÄãùêÉsuperscriptitalic-œµ2ùêÉ\\epsilon^{2}\\mathbf{D} in ( [2.2]In 2.2 How to measure node affinity? ‚Ä£ 2 Proposed Method: Intuition ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function")),

and approximate the n√ónùëõùëõn\\times n matrix of pairwise affinities, ùêíùêí\\mathbf{S}, as

As we said, our method captures the differences in the 1-step, 2-step, 3-step etc. neighborhoods in a weighted way; differences in long paths have smaller effect on the computation of the similarity measure than differences in short paths. Recall that œµ<1italic-œµ1\\epsilon<1, and
that ùêÄksuperscriptùêÄùëò\\mathbf{A}^{k} has information about the kùëòk-step paths. Notice that this is just the intuition behind our method; we do not use this simplified formula to find matrix ùêíùêí\\mathbf{S}.

### 2.4 Which properties should a similarity measure satisfy?

Let G1‚Äã(ùí±,‚Ñ∞1)subscriptùê∫1ùí±subscript‚Ñ∞1G\_{1}(\\mathcal{V},\\mathcal{E}\_{1}) and G2‚Äã(ùí±,‚Ñ∞2)subscriptùê∫2ùí±subscript‚Ñ∞2G\_{2}(\\mathcal{V},\\mathcal{E}\_{2}) be two graphs, and s‚Äãi‚Äãm‚Äã(G1,G2)‚àà\[0,1\]ùë†ùëñùëösubscriptùê∫1subscriptùê∫201sim(G\_{1},G\_{2})\\in\[0,1\] denote their similarity score. Then, we want the similarity measure to obey the following axioms:
{itemize\*}

_Identity property_: s‚Äãi‚Äãm‚Äã(G1,G1)=1ùë†ùëñùëösubscriptùê∫1subscriptùê∫11sim(G\_{1},G\_{1})=1

_Symmetric property_: s‚Äãi‚Äãm‚Äã(G1,G2)=s‚Äãi‚Äãm‚Äã(G2,G1)ùë†ùëñùëösubscriptùê∫1subscriptùê∫2ùë†ùëñùëösubscriptùê∫2subscriptùê∫1sim(G\_{1},G\_{2})=sim(G\_{2},G\_{1})

_Zero property_: s‚Äãi‚Äãm‚Äã(G1,G2)‚Üí0‚Üíùë†ùëñùëösubscriptùê∫1subscriptùê∫20sim(G\_{1},G\_{2})\\to 0 for n‚Üí‚àû‚Üíùëõn\\to\\infty, where G1subscriptùê∫1G\_{1} is the clique graph (KnsubscriptùêæùëõK\_{n}), and G2subscriptùê∫2G\_{2} is the empty graph (i.e., the edge sets are complementary).

Moreover, the measure must be:

#### (a) intuitive.

It should satisfy the following desired properties:
{enumerate\*}

\[ _Edge Importance_\] Changes that create disconnected components should be penalized more than changes that maintain the connectivity properties of the graphs.

\[ _Weight Awareness_\] In weighted graphs, the bigger the weight of the removed edge is, the greater the impact on the similarity measure should be.

\[ _Edge-‚ÄúSubmodularity‚Äù_\] A specific change is more important in a graph with few edges than in a much denser, but equally sized graph.

\[ _Focus Awareness_\] Random changes in graphs are less important than targeted changes of the same extent.

#### (b) scalable.

The huge size of the generated graphs, as well as their abundance require a similarity measure that is computed fast and handles graphs with billions of nodes.

3 Proposed Method: Details.content:
Now that we have described the high level ideas behind our method, we move on to the details.

### 3.1 Algorithm Description

Let the graphs we compare be G1‚Äã(ùí±,‚Ñ∞1)subscriptùê∫1ùí±subscript‚Ñ∞1G\_{1}(\\mathcal{V},\\mathcal{E}\_{1}) and G2‚Äã(ùí±,‚Ñ∞2)subscriptùê∫2ùí±subscript‚Ñ∞2G\_{2}(\\mathcal{V},\\mathcal{E}\_{2}). If the graphs have different node sets, say ùí±1subscriptùí±1\\mathcal{V}\_{1} and ùí±2subscriptùí±2\\mathcal{V}\_{2}, we assume that ùí±=ùí±1‚à™ùí±2ùí±subscriptùí±1subscriptùí±2\\mathcal{V}=\\mathcal{V}\_{1}\\cup\\mathcal{V}\_{2}, where some nodes are disconnected.

As mentioned before, the main idea behind our proposed similarity algorithm is to compare the node affinities in the given graphs. The steps of our similarity method are:

#### Step 1.

By eq. ( [2.2]In 2.2 How to measure node affinity? ‚Ä£ 2 Proposed Method: Intuition ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function")), we compute for each graph the n√ónùëõùëõn\\times n matrix of pairwise node affinity scores (ùêí1subscriptùêí1\\mathbf{S}\_{1} and ùêí2subscriptùêí2\\mathbf{S}\_{2} for graphs G1subscriptùê∫1G\_{1} and G2subscriptùê∫2G\_{2} respectively).

#### Step 2.

Among the various distance and similarity measures (e.g., Euclidean distance (ED), cosine similarity, correlation) found in the literature, we use the root euclidean distance (RootED, a.k.a. Matusita distance)

|     |     |     |     |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| (3.3) |  | d=RootED‚Äã(ùêí1,ùêí2)=‚àëi=1n‚àëj=1n(s1,i‚Äãj‚àís2,i‚Äãj)2.ùëëRootEDsubscriptùêí1subscriptùêí2superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùë†1ùëñùëósubscriptùë†2ùëñùëó2d=\\textsc{RootED}(\\mathbf{S}\_{1},\\mathbf{S}\_{2})=\\sqrt{\\sum\_{i=1}^{n}\\sum\_{j=1}^{n}{(\\sqrt{s\_{1,ij}}-\\sqrt{s\_{2,ij}}})^{2}}. |  |

We use the RootED distance for the following reasons:

{enumerate\*}

it is very similar to the Euclidean distance (ED), the only difference being the square root of the pairwise similarities (si‚Äãjsubscriptùë†ùëñùëós\_{ij}),

it usually gives better results, because it ‚Äúboosts‚Äù the node affinities333The node affinities are in \[0,1\]01\[0,1\], so the square root makes them bigger. and, therefore, detects even small changes in the graphs (other distance measures, including ED, suffer from high similarity scores no matter how much the graphs differ), and

satisfies the desired properties P‚Äã1ùëÉ1P1-P‚Äã4ùëÉ4P4. As discussed in the Appendix [A.5]A.5 Satisfaction of the Properties ‚Ä£ A Appendix ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function") of \[ [6])\], at least P‚Äã1ùëÉ1P1 is not satisfied by the ED.

#### Step 3.

For interpretability,
we convert the distance (dùëëd) to similarity measure (s‚Äãi‚Äãmùë†ùëñùëösim) via the formula s‚Äãi‚Äãm=11+dùë†ùëñùëö11ùëësim=\\frac{1}{1+d}.
The result is bounded to the interval \[0,1\], as opposed to being unbounded \[0,‚àû\\infty).\
Notice that the distance-to-similarity transformation\
does not change the ranking of results in a nearest-neighbor query.\
\
The straightforward algorithm, DeltaCon0 (Algorithm [1]Algorithm 1 ‚Ä£ Step 3. ‚Ä£ 3.1 Algorithm Description ‚Ä£ 3 Proposed Method: Details ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function")), is to compute all the n2superscriptùëõ2n^{2} affinity scores of matrix ùêíùêí\\mathbf{S} by simply using equation ( [2.2]In 2.2 How to measure node affinity? ‚Ä£ 2 Proposed Method: Intuition ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function")). We can do the inversion using the Power Method or any other efficient method.\

### 3.2 Scalability Analysis\
\
DeltaCon0 satisfies all the properties in Section [2]Proposed Method: Intuition ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function"),\
but it is quadratic (n2superscriptùëõ2n^{2} affinity scores si‚Äãjsubscriptùë†ùëñùëós\_{ij} \- using power method for the inversion of sparse matrix)\
and thus not scalable.\
We present a faster, linear algorithm, DeltaCon (Algorithm [2]Algorithm 2 ‚Ä£ 3.2 Scalability Analysis ‚Ä£ 3 Proposed Method: Details ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function")), which approximates DeltaCon0 and differs in the first step. We still want each node to become a seed exactly once in order to find the affinities of the rest of the nodes to it; but, here, we have multiple seeds at once, instead of having one seed at a time.\
The idea is to randomly divide our node-set into gùëîg groups, and compute\
the affinity score of each node iùëñi to group kùëòk, thus requiring\
only n√ógùëõùëîn\\times g scores, which are stored in the n√ógùëõùëîn\\times g matrix ùêí‚Ä≤superscriptùêí‚Ä≤\\mathbf{S}^{\\prime} (g‚â™nmuch-less-thanùëîùëõg\\ll n).\
Intuitively, instead of using the n√ónùëõùëõn\\times n affinity matrix ùêíùêí\\mathbf{S},\
we add up the scores of the columns that correspond to the nodes of a group,\
and obtain the n√ógùëõùëîn\\times g matrix ùêí‚Ä≤superscriptùêí‚Ä≤\\mathbf{S}^{\\prime} (g‚â™nmuch-less-thanùëîùëõg\\ll n).\
The score si‚Äãk‚Ä≤subscriptsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùëñùëòs^{\\prime}\_{ik} is the affinity of node iùëñi to the kt‚Äãhsuperscriptùëòùë°‚Ñék^{th}group of nodes (k=1,‚Ä¶,gùëò1‚Ä¶ùëîk=1,\\ldots,g).\
\
###### Lemma 3.1\
\
The time complexity of computing the reduced affinity matrix, ùêí‚Ä≤superscriptùêí‚Ä≤\\mathbf{S}^{\\prime}, is linear on the number of edges.\
\
- Proof.\
\
\
We can compute the n√ógùëõùëîn\\times g ‚Äúskinny‚Äù matrix ùêí‚Ä≤superscriptùêí‚Ä≤\\mathbf{S}^{\\prime} quickly,\
by solving \[ùêà+œµ2‚ÄãùêÉ‚àíœµ‚ÄãùêÄ\]‚Äãùêí‚Ä≤=\[s‚Üí01‚Äã‚Ä¶‚Äãs‚Üí0‚Äãg\],delimited-\[\]ùêàsuperscriptitalic-œµ2ùêÉitalic-œµùêÄsuperscriptùêí‚Ä≤delimited-\[\]subscript‚Üíùë†01‚Ä¶subscript‚Üíùë†0ùëî\[\\mathbf{I}+\\epsilon^{2}\\mathbf{D}-\\epsilon\\mathbf{A}\]\\mathbf{S}^{\\prime}=\[{\\vec{s}}\_{01}\\;\\ldots{\\vec{s}}\_{0g}\], where s‚Üí0‚Äãk=‚àëi‚ààg‚Äãr‚Äão‚Äãu‚Äãpke‚Üíisubscript‚Üíùë†0ùëòsubscriptùëñùëîùëüùëúùë¢subscriptùëùùëòsubscript‚Üíùëíùëñ{\\vec{s}}\_{0k}=\\sum\_{i\\in group\_{k}}\\vec{e}\_{i} is the membership n√ó1ùëõ1n\\times 1 vector for group kùëòk (all 0‚Äôs, except 1‚Äôs for members of the group). ‚ñ°‚ñ°\\square\
\
\
Thus, we compute gùëîg final scores per node, which denote its affinity to every _group_ of seeds, instead of every seed node that we had in eq. ( [2.2]In 2.2 How to measure node affinity? ‚Ä£ 2 Proposed Method: Intuition ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function")).\
With careful implementation, DeltaCon is linear on the number of number of edges and groups gùëîg. As we show in section [4.2]Scalability of DeltaCon. ‚Ä£ 4 Experiments ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function"),\
it takes ‚àº160similar-toabsent160\\sim 160sec, on commodity hardware, for a 1.6-million-node graph.\
\
Once we have the reduced affinity matrices ùêí1‚Ä≤subscriptsuperscriptùêí‚Ä≤1\\mathbf{S}^{\\prime}\_{1} and ùêí2‚Ä≤subscriptsuperscriptùêí‚Ä≤2\\mathbf{S}^{\\prime}\_{2} of the two graphs,\
we use the RootED, to find the similarity between the n√ógùëõùëîn\\times g matrices\
of final scores, where g‚â™nmuch-less-thanùëîùëõg\\ll n.\
\
###### Lemma 3.2\
\
The time complexity of DeltaCon, when applied in parallel to the input graphs, is linear on the number of edges in the graphs, i.e. O(g‚ãÖm‚Äãa‚Äãx‚Äã{m1,m2})‚ãÖùëîùëöùëéùë•subscriptùëö1subscriptùëö2(g\\cdot max\\{m\_{1},m\_{2}\\}).\
\
- Proof.\
\
\
Based on lemma [3.1]Lemma 3.1 ‚Ä£ 3.2 Scalability Analysis ‚Ä£ 3 Proposed Method: Details ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function"). See Appendix [A.3]A.3 Proofs for Section 3 ‚Ä£ A Appendix ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function") in \[ [6])\]. ‚ñ°‚ñ°\\square\
\
\
###### Theorem 1\
\
DeltaCon‚Äôs similarity score between any two graphs G1subscriptùê∫1G\_{1}, G2subscriptùê∫2G\_{2} upper bounds the actual DeltaCon0‚Äôs similarity score, i.e. s‚Äãi‚ÄãmD‚ÄãC‚àí0‚Äã(G1,G2)‚â§s‚Äãi‚ÄãmD‚ÄãC‚Äã(G1,G2)ùë†ùëñsubscriptùëöùê∑ùê∂0subscriptùê∫1subscriptùê∫2ùë†ùëñsubscriptùëöùê∑ùê∂subscriptùê∫1subscriptùê∫2sim\_{DC-0}(G\_{1},G\_{2})\\leq sim\_{DC}(G\_{1},G\_{2}).\
\
- Proof.\
\
\
Intuitively, grouping nodes blurs the influence information and makes the nodes seem more similar than originally. For more details, see Appendix [A.3]A.3 Proofs for Section 3 ‚Ä£ A Appendix ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function") of \[ [6])\]. ‚ñ°‚ñ°\\square\
\
\
In the following section we show that DeltaCon (which includes DeltaCon0 as a special case for g=nùëîùëõg=n) satisfies the axioms and properties, while in the Appendix ( [A.4]A.4 Satisfaction of the Axioms ‚Ä£ A Appendix ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function") and [A.5]A.5 Satisfaction of the Properties ‚Ä£ A Appendix ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function") in \[ [6])\]) we provide the proofs.\

For each graph we create 8 ‚Äúcorrupted‚Äù versions with 10% to 80% fewer edges than the initial graphs. Notice that all the points are above the diagonal.\
\
To answer Q1, for the first 3 properties (P1-P3), we conduct experiments on small graphs of 5 to 100 nodes and classic topologies (cliques, stars, circles, paths, barbell and wheel-barbell graphs, and ‚Äúlollipops‚Äù shown in Fig. [2]Figure 2 ‚Ä£ 4.1 Intuitiveness of DeltaCon. ‚Ä£ 4 Experiments ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function")), since people can argue about their similarities. For the name conventions see Table 3. For our method we used 5 groups (gùëîg), but the results are similar for other choices of the parameter. In addition to the synthetic graphs, for the last property (P4), we use real networks with up to 11 million edges (Table [2]Table 2 ‚Ä£ 4 Experiments ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function")).\
\
We compare our method, DeltaCon, to the 6 best state-of-the-art similarity measures that apply to our setting:\
{enumerate\*}\
\

Signature Similarity (SS) \[ [5])\]: This is the best performing similarity measure studied in \[ [5])\]. It is based on the SimHash algorithm (random projection based method).\
\
The last 3 methods are variations of the well-studied spectral method ‚ÄúŒªùúÜ\\lambda-distance‚Äù (\[ [4])\], \[ [11])\], \[ [12])\]). Let {Œª1‚Äãi}i=1\|ùí±1\|\\lambda\_{1i}\\}\_{i=1}^{\|\\mathcal{V}\_{1}\|} and {Œª2‚Äãi}i=1\|ùí±2\|\\lambda\_{2i}\\}\_{i=1}^{\|\\mathcal{V}\_{2}\|} be the eigenvalues of the matrices that represent G1subscriptùê∫1G\_{1} and G2subscriptùê∫2G\_{2}. Then, ŒªùúÜ\\lambda-distance is given by\
\

|  | dŒª‚Äã(G1,G2)=‚àëi=1k(Œª1‚Äãi‚àíŒª2‚Äãi)2,subscriptùëëùúÜsubscriptùê∫1subscriptùê∫2superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùúÜ1ùëñsubscriptùúÜ2ùëñ2d\_{\\lambda}(G\_{1},G\_{2})=\\sqrt{\\sum\_{i=1}^{k}{(\\lambda\_{1i}-\\lambda\_{2i})}^{2}}, |  |\
\
where kùëòk is m‚Äãa‚Äãx‚Äã(\|ùí±1\|,\|ùí±2\|)ùëöùëéùë•subscriptùí±1subscriptùí±2max(\|\\mathcal{V}\_{1}\|,\|\\mathcal{V}\_{2}\|) (padding is required for the smallest vector of eigenvalues).\
The variations of the method are based on three different matrix representations of the graphs: adjacency (ŒªùúÜ\\lambda-d Adj.), laplacian (ŒªùúÜ\\lambda-d Lap.) and normalized laplacian matrix (ŒªùúÜ\\lambda-d N.L.).\
\
The results for the first 3 properties are presented in the form of tables [4]Table 4 ‚Ä£ 4.1 Intuitiveness of DeltaCon. ‚Ä£ 4 Experiments ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function")- [6]Table 6 ‚Ä£ 4.1 Intuitiveness of DeltaCon. ‚Ä£ 4 Experiments ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function"). For property P1 we compare the graphs (A,B) and (A,C) and report the difference between the pairwise similarities/distances of our proposed methods and the 6 state-of-the-art methods. We have arranged the pairs of graphs in such way that (A,B) are more similar than (A,C). Therefore, table entries that are non-positive mean that the corresponding method does not satisfy the property. Similarly, for properties P2 and P3, we compare the graphs (A,B) and (C,D) and report the difference in their pairwise similarity/distance scores.\
\
#### P1. Edge Importance\
\
:\
_‚ÄúEdges whose removal creates disconnected components are more important than other edges whose absence does not affect the graph connectivity. The more important an edge is, the more it should affect the similarity or distance measure.‚Äù_\
\
For this experiment we use the barbell, ‚Äúwheel barbell‚Äù and ‚Äúlollipop‚Äù graphs, since it is easy to argue about the importance of the individual edges. The idea is that edges _in_ a highly connected component (e.g. clique, wheel) are not very important from the information flow viewpoint, while edges that _connect_ (almost uniquely) dense components play a significant role in the connectivity of the graph and the information flow. The importance of the ‚Äúbridge‚Äù edge depends on the size of the components that it connects; the bigger the components the more important is the role of the edge.\
\
###### Observation 1\
\
Only DeltaCon succeeds in distinguishing the importance of the edges (P‚Äã1)ùëÉ1(P1) w.r.t. connectivity, while all the other methods fail at least once (Table [4]Table 4 ‚Ä£ 4.1 Intuitiveness of DeltaCon. ‚Ä£ 4 Experiments ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function")).\
\
#### P2. Weight Awareness\
\
:\
_‚ÄúThe absence of an edge of big weight is more important than the absence of a smaller weighted edge; this should be reflected in the similarity measure.‚Äù_\
\
The weight of an edge defines the strength of the connection between two nodes, and, in this sense, can be viewed as a feature that relates to the importance of the edge in the graph. For this property, we study the weighted versions of the barbell graph, where we assume that all the edges except the ‚Äúbridge‚Äù have unit weight.\
\
###### Observation 2\
\
All the methods are weight-aware (P‚Äã2)ùëÉ2(P2), except VEO and GED which compute just the overlap in edges and vertices between the graphs (Table [5]Table 5 ‚Ä£ Figure 3 ‚Ä£ 4.1 Intuitiveness of DeltaCon. ‚Ä£ 4 Experiments ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function")).\
\
#### P3. ‚ÄúEdge-Submodularity‚Äù\
\
:\
_‚ÄúLet A‚Äã(ùí±,‚Ñ∞1)ùê¥ùí±subscript‚Ñ∞1A(\\mathcal{V},\\mathcal{E}\_{1}) and B‚Äã(ùí±,‚Ñ∞2)ùêµùí±subscript‚Ñ∞2B(\\mathcal{V},\\mathcal{E}\_{2}) be two graphs with the same node set, and \|‚Ñ∞1\|>\|‚Ñ∞2\|subscript‚Ñ∞1subscript‚Ñ∞2\|\\mathcal{E}\_{1}\|>\|\\mathcal{E}\_{2}\| edges. Also, assume that mx‚ÄãA‚Äã(ùí±,‚Ñ∞1)subscriptùëöùë•ùê¥ùí±subscript‚Ñ∞1m\_{x}A(\\mathcal{V},\\mathcal{E}\_{1}) and mx‚ÄãB‚Äã(ùí±,‚Ñ∞2)subscriptùëöùë•ùêµùí±subscript‚Ñ∞2m\_{x}B(\\mathcal{V},\\mathcal{E}\_{2}) are the respective derived graphs after removing xùë•x edges. We expect that s‚Äãi‚Äãm‚Äã(A,mx‚ÄãA)>s‚Äãi‚Äãm‚Äã(B,mx‚ÄãB)ùë†ùëñùëöùê¥subscriptùëöùë•ùê¥ùë†ùëñùëöùêµsubscriptùëöùë•ùêµsim(A,m\_{x}A)>sim(B,m\_{x}B), since the fewer the edges in a constant-sized graph, the more ‚Äúimportant‚Äù they are.‚Äù_\
\
The results for different graph topologies and 1 or 10 removed edges (prefixes ‚Äôm‚Äô and ‚Äôm10‚Äô respectively) are given compactly in Table [6]Table 6 ‚Ä£ 4.1 Intuitiveness of DeltaCon. ‚Ä£ 4 Experiments ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function"). Recall that non-positive values denote violation of the ‚Äúedge-submodularity‚Äù property.\
\
###### Observation 3\
\
Only DeltaCon complies to the ‚Äúedge-submodularity‚Äù property (P‚Äã3)ùëÉ3(P3) in all cases examined.\
\
#### P4. Focus Awareness\
\
:\
At this point, all the competing methods have failed in satisfying at least one of the desired properties. To test whether DeltaCon is able to distinguish the extent of a change in a graph, we analyze real datasets with up to 11 million edges (Table [2]Table 2 ‚Ä£ 4 Experiments ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function")) for two different types of changes. For each graph we create corrupted instances by removing: (i) edges from the original graph randomly, and (ii) the same number of edges in a targeted way (we randomly choose nodes and remove all their edges, until we have removed the appropriate fraction of edges).\
\
In Fig. [4.1]Intuitiveness of DeltaCon. ‚Ä£ 4 Experiments ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function"), for each of the 4 real networks -Email EU, Enron, Google web and AS Skitter-, we give the pair (sim\_DeltaCon random, sim\_DeltaCon targeted) for each of the different levels of corruption (10%, 20%, ‚Ä¶, 80%). That is, for each corruption level and network, there is a point with coordinates the similarity score between the original graph and the corrupted graph when the edge removal is random, and the score when the edge removal is targeted. The line y=xùë¶ùë•y=x corresponds to equal similarity scores for both ways of removing edges.\
\
###### Observation 4\
\
{itemize\*}\
\
_‚ÄúTargeted changes hurt more.‚Äù_DeltaCon is focus-aware (P‚Äã4)ùëÉ4(P4). Removal of edges in a targeted way leads to smaller similarity of the derived graph to the original one than removal of the same number of edges in a random way.\
\
_‚ÄúMore changes: random ‚âà\\approx targeted.‚Äù_ As the corruption level increases, the similarity score for random changes tends to the similarity score for targeted changes (in Fig. [4.1]Intuitiveness of DeltaCon. ‚Ä£ 4 Experiments ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function"), all lines converge to the y=xùë¶ùë•y=x line for greater level of corruption).\
\
This is expected as the random and targeted edge removal tend to be equivalent when a significant fraction of edges is deleted.\
\
General Remarks.\
All in all, the baseline methods have several non-desirable properties. The spectral methods, as well as SS fail to comply to the ‚Äúedge importance‚Äù (P1) and ‚Äúedge submodularity‚Äù (P3) properties. Moreover, ŒªùúÜ\\lambda-distance has high computational cost when the whole graph spectrum is computed, cannot\
distinguish the differences between co-spectral graphs, and sometimes small changes lead to big differences in the graph spectra. As far as VEO and GED are concerned, they are oblivious on significant structural properties of the graphs; thus, despite their straightforwardness and fast computation, they fail to discern various changes in the graphs.\
On the other hand, DeltaCon gives tangible similarity scores and conforms to all the desired properties.\
\
### 4.2 Scalability of DeltaCon.\
\
In Section [2]Proposed Method: Intuition ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function") we demonstrated that DeltaCon is linear on the number of edges, and here we show that this also holds in practice.\
We ran DeltaCon on Kronecker graphs (Table [2]Table 2 ‚Ä£ 4 Experiments ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function")), which are known \[ [13])\] to share many properties with real graphs.\
\
###### Observation 5\
\
As shown in Fig. [4]Figure 4 ‚Ä£ 4.2 Scalability of DeltaCon. ‚Ä£ 4 Experiments ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function"), DeltaCon scales linearly with the number of edges in the graph.\
\
Notice that the algorithm can be trivially parallelized by finding the node affinity scores of the two graphs in parallel instead of sequential. Moreover, for each graph the computation of the similarity scores of the nodes to each of the gùëîg groups can be parallelized. However, the runtime of our experiments refer to the sequential implementation.\
\
![Refer to caption]Figure 4: DeltaCon is linear on the number of edges (time in sec. vs. number of edges). The exact number of edges is annotated.\
\

5 DeltaCon at Work\\.content:
\
In this section we present two applications of graph similarity measures; we use DeltaCon and report our findings.\
\
![Refer to caption]Figure 5: Graph Anomaly Detection with DeltaCon. The marked days correspond to anomalies and coincide with major events in the history of Enron. The blue points are similarity scores between consecutive instances of the daily email activity between the employees, and the marked days are 3‚ÄãœÉ3ùúé3\\sigma units away from the median similarity score.\
\
### 5.1 Enron.\
\
First, we analyze the time-evolving ENRON graph. Figure [5]Figure 5 ‚Ä£ 5 DeltaCon at Work ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function") depicts the similarity scores between consecutive daily who-emailed-whom graphs. By applying Quality Control with Individual Moving Range, we obtain the lower and upper limits of the in-control similarity scores. These limits correspond to median ¬±3‚ÄãœÉplus-or-minus3ùúé\\pm 3\\sigma (The median is used instead of the mean, since appropriate hypothesis tests demonstrate that the data does not follow the normal distribution. Moving range mean is used to estimate œÉùúé\\sigma.). Using this method we were able to define the threshold (lower control limit) below which the corresponding days are anomalous, i.e. they differ ‚Äútoo much‚Äù from the previous and following days.\
Note that all the anomalous days relate to crucial events in the company‚Äôs history during 2001 (points marked with red boxes in Fig. [5]Figure 5 ‚Ä£ 5 DeltaCon at Work ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function")):\
(2) 8/21, Lay emails all employees stating he wants ‚Äúto restore investor confidence in Enron.‚Äù;\
(3) 9/26, Lay tells employees that the accounting practices are ‚Äúlegal and totally appropriate‚Äù, and that the stock is ‚Äúan incredible bargain.‚Äù;\
(4) 10/5, Just before Arthur Andersen hired Davis Polk & Wardwell law firm to prepare a defense for the company;\
(5) 10/24-25, Jeff McMahon takes over as CFO. Email to all employees states that all the pertinent documents should be preserved;\
(6) 11/8, Enron announces it overstated profits by 586 million dollars over 5 years.\
\
Although high similarities between consecutive days do not consist anomalies, we found that mostly weekends expose high similarities. For instance, the first two points of 100% similarity correspond to the weekend before Christmas in 2000 and a weekend in July, when only two employees sent emails to each other. It is noticeable that after February 2002 many consecutive days are very similar; this happens because, after the collapse of Enron, the email exchange activity was rather low and often between certain employees.\
\
### 5.2 Brain Connectivity Graph Clustering.\
\
We also use DeltaCon for clustering and classification. For this purpose we study _conectomes_ -brain graphs-, which are obtained by Multimodal Magnetic Resonance Imaging \[ [14])\].\
\
In total we study the connectomes of 114 people; each consists of 70 cortical regions (nodes), and connections (weighted edges) between them. We ignore the strength of connections and derive an undirected, unweighted brain graph per person. In addition to the connectomes, we have attributes for each person (e.g., age, gender, IQ).\
\
We first get the DeltaCon pairwise similarities between the brain graphs, and then perform hierarchical clustering using Ward‚Äôs method (Fig. [1(b)]In Figure 1 ‚Ä£ 1 Introduction ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function")). As shown in the figure, there are two clearly separable groups of brain graphs. Applying t-test on the available attributes for the two groups created by the clusters, we found that the latter differ significantly (p-value=0.0057) in the Composite Creativity Index (CCI), which is related to the person‚Äôs performance on a series of creativity tasks. Moreover, the two groups correspond to low and high openness index (p-value=0.0558), one of the ‚ÄúBig Five Factors‚Äù; that is, the brain connectivity is different in people that are inventive and people that are consistent. Exploiting analysis of variance (ANOVA: generalization of t-test when more than 2 groups are analyzed), we tested whether the various clusters that we obtain from hierarchical clustering reflect the structural differences in the brain graphs. However, in the dataset we studied there is no sufficient statistical evidence that age, gender, IQ etc. are related to the brain connectivity.\
\

6 Related Work\\.content:
\
Graph Similarity. The problems are divided in two main categories:\
_(1) With Known Node Correspondence._\
Papadimitriou et al. \[ [5])\] propose 5 similarity measures for directed web graphs. Among them the best is the Signature Similarity (SS), which is based on the SimHash algorithm, while the Vertex/Edge Overlap similarity (VEO) performs very well. Bunke \[ [4])\] presents techniques used to track sudden changes in communications networks for performance monitoring. The best approaches are the Graph Edit Distance and Maximum Common Subgraph. Both are NP-complete, but the former approach can be simplified given the application and it becomes linear on the number of nodes and edges in the graphs.\
_(2) With Unknown Node Correspondence._ Two approaches can be used: (a) feature extraction and similarity computation, (b) graph matching and application of techniques from the first category \[ [15])\], (c) graph kernels \[ [16])\].\
The research directions in this category include: ŒªùúÜ\\lambda-distance (\[ [4])\],\[ [11])\],\[ [12])\]), a spectral method that has been studied thoroughly; algebraic connectivity \[ [17])\]; an SVM-based approach on global feature vectors \[ [18])\]; social networks similarity \[ [19])\]; computing edge curvatures under heat kernel embedding \[ [20])\]; comparison of the number of spanning trees \[ [21])\]; fast random walk graph kernel \[ [22])\].\
\
Both research directions are important, but apply in different settings; if the node correspondence is available, the algorithms that make use of it can perform only better than methods that omit it. Here we tackle the former problem.\
\
Node affinity algorithms. There are numerous node affinity algorithms; Pagerank \[ [23])\], Personalized Random Walks with Restarts \[ [24])\], the electric network analogy \[ [25])\], SimRank \[ [26])\], and Belief Propagation \[ [27])\] are only some examples of the most successful techniques. Here we focus on the latter method, and specifically a fast variation \[ [28])\] which is also intuitive. All the techniques have been used successfully in many tasks, such as ranking, classification, malware and fraud detection (\[ [29])\],\[ [30])\]), and recommendation systems \[ [31])\].\
\

7 Conclusions\\.content:
\
In this work, we tackle the problem of graph similarity\
when the node correspondence is known (e.g., similarity in\
time-evolving phone\
networks). Our contributions are:\
\
{itemize\*}\
\
_Axioms/Properties_: we formalize the problem of graph similarity by providing axioms, and desired properties.\
\
_Algorithm_: We propose DeltaCon, an algorithm that is (a) _principled_ (axioms A‚Äã1ùê¥1A1-A‚Äã3ùê¥3A3, in Sec. [2]Proposed Method: Intuition ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function")), (b) _intuitive_ (properties P‚Äã1ùëÉ1P1-P‚Äã4ùëÉ4P4, in Sec. [4]Experiments ‚Ä£ DeltaCon: A Principled Massive-Graph Similarity Function")), and (c) _scalable_, needing on commodity hardware ~160 seconds for a graph with over 67 million edges.\
\
_Experiments_: We evaluate the intuitiveness of DeltaCon, and compare it to 6 state-of-the-art measures.\
\
_Applications_: We use DeltaCon for temporal anomaly detection (ENRON), and clustering & classification (brain graphs).\
\
Future work includes parallelizing our algorithm, as well as trying to partition the graphs in a more informative way (e.g., using elimination tree) than random.\
\

8 Acknowledgements\\.content:
\

bib.bib22.abstract:
How much did a network change since yesterday? How different is the wiring
between Bob's brain (a left-handed male) and Alice's brain (a right-handed
female)? Graph similarity with known node correspondence, i.e. the detection of
changes in the connectivity of graphs, arises in numerous settings. In this
work, we formally state the axioms and desired properties of the graph
similarity functions, and evaluate when state-of-the-art methods fail to detect
crucial connectivity changes in graphs. We propose DeltaCon, a principled,
intuitive, and scalable algorithm that assesses the similarity between two
graphs on the same nodes (e.g. employees of a company, customers of a mobile
carrier). Experiments on various synthetic and real graphs showcase the
advantages of our method over existing similarity measures. Finally, we employ
DeltaCon to real applications: (a) we classify people to groups of high and low
creativity based on their brain connectivity graphs, and (b) do temporal
anomaly detection in the who-emails-whom Enron graph.
